guide.conclusion: You can get a kit of parts for your own EL wire project at the Adafruit shop.
guide.introduction:
Tote your Thinkpad and port your Apple in style with our custom TRON-inspired laptop bag tutorial. With a little soldering and sewing skills you can have your own light-up satchel, sure to impress geeky friends. So grab your sewing needle and soldering iron and follow along.

This project was a collaboration between ladyada & becky stern, rock!
guide.introduction_rendered:
Tote your Thinkpad and port your Apple in style with our custom TRON-inspired laptop bag tutorial. With a little soldering and sewing skills you can have your own light-up satchel, sure to impress geeky friends. So grab your sewing needle and soldering iron and follow along.

This project was a collaboration between ladyada & becky stern, rock!

Relevant parts
  • EL wire
  • EL Inverter with connectors
  • Copper tape
  • Heat-shrink tubing
  • Insulated stranded hookup wire 22-gauge
  • invisible thread
Tools
  • Hair dryer heat gun or lighter
  • Scissors
  • Sewing needle
  • Soldering iron solder
  • Wire strippers cutters

parts.notes: you can get this at craft stores in the glassworking area

lines.text: The first step is to plan out your design. We did this on some graph paper.
lines.text_raw: The first step is to plan out your design. We did this on some graph paper.

lines.text: EL wire is stiff and holds its shape but can't be bent many times or it will break (like any stiff wire). For that reason, you'll want to try and keep the wires on large flat surfaces or going around edges that don't flex.
lines.text_raw: EL wire is stiff and holds its shape but can't be bent many times or it will break (like any stiff wire). For that reason, you'll want to try and keep the wires on large flat surfaces or going around edges that don't flex.

lines.text: Gather tools and supplies.
lines.text_raw: Gather tools and supplies.

lines.text: The nice thing about most laptop bags is that they have a flap and pockets with strong piping and corners to protect the computer. We'll take advantage of that!
lines.text_raw: The nice thing about most laptop bags is that they have a flap and pockets with strong piping and corners to protect the computer. We'll take advantage of that!

lines.text: We're going to put a design on the large front flap. We'll start by chalking it out.
lines.text_raw: We're going to put a design on the large front flap. We'll start by chalking it out.

lines.text: Think about how you want the EL wire to travel around the bag.
lines.text_raw: Think about how you want the EL wire to travel around the bag.

lines.text: EL is hard to solder to, and harder to 'split' so keeping it simple is key!
lines.text_raw: EL is hard to solder to, and harder to 'split' so keeping it simple is key!

lines.text: You'll want to have all the ends terminate near a pocket that will hold the inverter.
lines.text_raw: You'll want to have all the ends terminate near a pocket that will hold the inverter.

lines.text: Since the pocket-sized AA inverters can only drive 2 or 3 meters or wire maximum, it's smart to keep the design short and sweet. Keep track of how long the final wire will be; add up all the segments and keep the number under 2.5m for the best look.
lines.text_raw: Since the pocket-sized AA inverters can only drive 2 or 3 meters or wire maximum, it's smart to keep the design short and sweet. Keep track of how long the final wire will be; add up all the segments and keep the number under 2.5m for the best look.

lines.text: Of course, you can also use a larger inverter or two inverters!
lines.text_raw: Of course, you can also use a larger inverter or two inverters!

lines.text: Now that you have your pattern, it's time to start working with the EL wire.
lines.text_raw: Now that you have your pattern, it's time to start working with the EL wire.

lines.text: If you've used EL before, it might be easier for you to cut EL pieces to match the traced-out pattern.
lines.text_raw: If you've used EL before, it might be easier for you to cut EL pieces to match the traced-out pattern.

lines.text: We're EL wire experts, but if you're still not really good with EL or if you're just starting out, don't cut any pieces yet! Instead, solder up one EL wire at a time and then lay it out and cut the end. This is because it can take a few tries to solder to EL and every time you make a mistake you'll have to cut another 1 cm off and start over.
lines.text_raw: We're EL wire experts, but if you're still not really good with EL or if you're just starting out, don't cut any pieces yet! Instead, solder up one EL wire at a time and then lay it out and cut the end. This is because it can take a few tries to solder to EL and every time you make a mistake you'll have to cut another 1 cm off and start over.

lines.text: We wanted to have a 'broken' wire detail in the center of the bag to match the TRON detailing observed in the movie. We did this by slipping some heat shrink over the EL wire to 'black out' the light. Much easier than trying to solder it to a short piece of wire.
lines.text_raw: We wanted to have a 'broken' wire detail in the center of the bag to match the TRON detailing observed in the movie. We did this by slipping some heat shrink over the EL wire to 'black out' the light. Much easier than trying to solder it to a short piece of wire.

lines.text: Go over to our detailed EL wire tutorial (you'll want to keep it up on your web browser as you solder all the pieces), and attach a connector so that you can connect it to the EL inverter.
lines.text_raw: Go over to our [link|http://www.ladyada.net/learn/el-wire/index.html|detailed EL wire tutorial] (you'll want to keep it up on your web browser as you solder all the pieces), and attach a connector so that you can connect it to the EL inverter.

lines.text: Once you've soldered your connector on, attach it to the inverter and test it to make sure the EL is glowing.
lines.text_raw: Once you've soldered your connector on, attach it to the inverter and test it to make sure the EL is glowing.

lines.text: Now disconnect the wire from the inverter. Never cut EL wire while it's lit! And don't cut it yet; we'll do that in a later step.
lines.text_raw: Now disconnect the wire from the inverter. Never cut EL wire while it's lit! And don't cut it yet; we'll do that in a later step.

lines.text: Now we'll start sewing the EL onto the bag. We suggest using 'invisible' thread - also known as nylon thread. It's strong and clear so that it wont distract from your EL.
lines.text_raw: Now we'll start sewing the EL onto the bag. We suggest using 'invisible' thread - also known as nylon thread. It's strong and clear so that it wont distract from your EL.

lines.text: Place the inverter connected to the EL in the pocket you think is best. This will let you best judge how much wire you need. Be sure to try opening and closing the bag so you don't make any mistakes.
lines.text_raw: Place the inverter connected to the EL in the pocket you think is best. This will let you best judge how much wire you need. Be sure to try opening and closing the bag so you don't make any mistakes.

lines.text: Its easy to cut EL wire down but impossible to make it longer so measure twice and cut once!
lines.text_raw: Its easy to cut EL wire down but impossible to make it longer so measure twice and cut once!

lines.text: Lay the EL wire so it traces the chalk outline (or piping). In this photo the EL is lit but we don't necessarily suggest that you sew it lit unless it helps you visualize the design. Use masking tape to keep the EL wire in place.
lines.text_raw: Lay the EL wire so it traces the chalk outline (or piping). In this photo the EL is lit but we don't necessarily suggest that you sew it lit unless it helps you visualize the design. Use masking tape to keep the EL wire in place.

lines.text: Start at the "inverter" end.
lines.text_raw: Start at the "inverter" end.

lines.text: Use the needle and thread to wrap around the EL wire and tack it down. A stitch every centimeter is fine for long runs. We suggest grabbing plenty of the underlying material to provide a strong grip.
lines.text_raw: Use the needle and thread to wrap around the EL wire and tack it down. A stitch every centimeter is fine for long runs. We suggest grabbing plenty of the underlying material to provide a strong grip.

lines.text: Once you have traced the pattern, then you should cut the end with wirecutters! (Again, don't cut while it's on.)
lines.text_raw: Once you have traced the pattern, then you should cut the end with wirecutters! (Again, don't cut while it's on.)

lines.text: You can cap the EL wire for protection with a piece of small heatshrink. While it's still warm, squeeze it with pliers to seal it.
lines.text_raw: You can cap the EL wire for protection with a piece of small heatshrink. While it's still warm, squeeze it with pliers to seal it.

lines.text: Continue with all the pieces, taping them down and sewing them, making sure that all the connector ends wind up in the same pocket. You can see here how it all goes to the top left corner.
lines.text_raw: Continue with all the pieces, taping them down and sewing them, making sure that all the connector ends wind up in the same pocket. You can see here how it all goes to the top left corner.

lines.text: For the pocket detail, we wanted to have a piece of EL that split in two. This is possible but a little trickier than just a single piece.
lines.text_raw: For the pocket detail, we wanted to have a piece of EL that split in two. This is possible but a little trickier than just a single piece.

lines.text: Make sure you're comfortable with soldering to EL wire since you'll need to solder to two ends, thus doubling the difficulty.
lines.text_raw: Make sure you're comfortable with soldering to EL wire since you'll need to solder to two ends, thus doubling the difficulty.

lines.text: You'll want to cut the first piece a little long, again, and then solder two pieces of copper ribbon or other thin stranded wire to both the core and corona wires. Each one can go to another EL piece.
lines.text_raw: You'll want to cut the first piece a little long, again, and then solder two pieces of copper ribbon or other thin stranded wire to both the core and corona wires. Each one can go to another EL piece.

lines.text: Almost done! Once the EL wire is all sewn on make sure to test each strand again to make sure they are still strong and connected. Double-check all the heatshrink as well.
lines.text_raw: Almost done! Once the EL wire is all sewn on make sure to test each strand again to make sure they are still strong and connected. Double-check all the heatshrink as well.

lines.text: You can pass the wires around the bag or, if it's easier and you're OK with permanent modification, punch a hole and pass the wires through. This can be a little neater, less obviously modded.
lines.text_raw: You can pass the wires around the bag or, if it's easier and you're OK with permanent modification, punch a hole and pass the wires through. This can be a little neater, less obviously modded.

lines.text: Finally we will connect the strands to the inverter. There are inverters that will 'animate' the strands but we like the 'solid on' look which also matches the TRON movie best.
lines.text_raw: Finally we will connect the strands to the inverter. There are inverters that will 'animate' the strands but we like the 'solid on' look which also matches the TRON movie best.

lines.text: The only problem is we have 4 wires and we want to run them off of one inverter. We'll solve this problem by making a splitter, taking the one output of the inverter and allowing it to drive two EL wires. You can do this for as many strands as you'd like; just add up all the EL lengths and make sure the inverter will drive that much wire.
lines.text_raw: The only problem is we have 4 wires and we want to run them off of one inverter. We'll solve this problem by making a splitter, taking the one output of the inverter and allowing it to drive two EL wires. You can do this for as many strands as you'd like; just add up all the EL lengths and make sure the inverter will drive that much wire.

lines.text: Solder and heat-shrink the wires.
lines.text_raw: Solder and heat-shrink the wires.

lines.text: Use the splitter on the inverter (we used two inverters with two splitters here).
lines.text_raw: Use the splitter on the inverter (we used two inverters with two splitters here).

lines.text: Store the inverters in one of the front pockets.
lines.text_raw: Store the inverters in one of the front pockets.

lines.text: You're done! Enjoy your TRON bag.
